Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of kneeling man, with large flaccid phallus resting on floor. Mould-made and hollow. White coating traces on cloak. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that was operational between the 3rd and 2nd century BC. ‘Processional’ cult attendant with exaggerated phallus. Possibly Theophoros (god bearer). 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 2008, no. 3151), but also Roman examples have been found (Bailey 2008, no. 3152 and 3153; Dunand 1990; 189, no. 512, 514, 515 and 517). Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.484) (Phase 1)
